questions.text: A 25-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after being struck on his head by the house door and temporarily fainting. On examination, his sensorium was intact. NCCT head was performed and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Concussion

questions.text: All of the following are correctly paired with HU on CT except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fat: 0-20

 

  • Fat typically has a HU range of approximately -100 to -50, which means it appears less dense than water (0 HU) on CT scans. The value 0-20 HU does not correspond to fat but rather to other soft tissues or fluids.
  • Contrast material generally ranges from 100-300 HU depending on concentration, so 130 HU is a reasonable value for contrast-enhanced areas.
  • Acute hemorrhage usually has a HU range around 60-70, reflecting the density of fresh blood on CT.
  • Calcification appears hyperdense on CT, with very high HU values often between 800-1000 or higher, representing dense calcium deposits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contrast: 130: This is a typical attenuation value for iodinated contrast in vessels or organs on CT scan and falls within expected ranges.

 

Option C. Acute hemorrhage: 60-70: Fresh blood appears hyperdense on CT, commonly with HU values in this range.

 

Option D. Calcification: 800-1000: Dense calcium deposits have very high attenuation, consistent with this HU range on CT.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a history of transient ischemic attacks and several episodes of weakness is referred for diagnostic evaluation. On physical examination, there is a noticeable murmur around the child's temple. Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is performed, revealing the characteristic imaging shown. The following appearance of DSA is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moya-Moya disease

 

The angiographic image demonstrates a classic “puff of smoke” appearance, which is characteristic of Moya-Moya disease. This disease involves progressive stenosis of the internal carotid arteries and compensatory development of a fine network of collateral vessels, leading to the described smoky vascular pattern on DSA.

 

Moya-Moya typically presents in children with recurrent transient ischemic attacks and focal neurological deficits. The presence of a bruit (vascular murmur) over the temple further supports the diagnosis due to increased collateral flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ICA aneurysm: Would show a localized outpouching or ballooning of the vessel on angiography, not a diffuse network of vessels.

 

 

Option C. Cerebral infarction: Usually results in hypoperfusion zones or absence of flow.

 

Option D. Carotid artery thrombosis: Would show abrupt cutoff or absence of flow in the involved vessel, without the collateral vascularization seen here.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Superficial temporal artery

choices.text: It can cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB)
Paramagnetic material which can shorten the T1 relaxation time
Long-term studies show gadolinium deposition in the basal ganglia at high doses

questions.text: During a radiology department seminar, a discussion focuses on the properties and safety of gadolinium-based contrast agents. Which of the following statements about gadolinium is false?
questions.solution: Ans. A) It can cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB)

questions.text: In a male child having recurrent urinary problems, an imaging as done was shown. What is the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopic Ablation

 

The image shows dilated posterior urethra suggestive of posterior urethral valves. Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are congenital obstructive lesions in the male urethra that cause significant urinary problems, including recurrent infections, urinary retention, and potential renal damage due to backpressure effects on the kidneys. The preferred management for a significant PUV is endoscopic ablation, also known as cystoscopic ablation. This procedure involves using an endoscope to visualize and ablate (remove) the obstructing valves, thereby relieving the obstruction and improving urinary flow. Endoscopic ablation is the treatment of choice due to its effectiveness in directly addressing the obstructive lesion and preventing further complications.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dilation of urethra: Urethral dilation may be used in very early or minor cases of PUV but is generally not considered the primary treatment choice due to the risk of recurrence and inadequate relief of obstruction.

 

Option C. Dilation of urethra and bladder: This approach is not appropriate for managing PUV as it does not address the obstructive nature of the valves and is ineffective in resolving the underlying pathology.

 

Option D. Excision of verumontanum: The verumontanum is a structure within the urethra that is not involved in the formation of PUVs, and its excision would not resolve the problem. This option is incorrect and not a part of standard management for PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ablation is the definitive treatment for posterior urethral valves in children, providing direct relief of the obstruction and reducing the risk of renal damage.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed, which revealed multiple ring-enhancing lesions. What will be the next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MR spectroscopy

 

MR spectroscopy is the next best step when multiple ring-enhancing lesions are observed in the basal parts of the brain, suggesting tuberculomas. MR spectroscopy helps differentiate tuberculomas from other similar conditions, like neurocysticercosis (NCC), by identifying a characteristic lipid-lactate peak. The presence of this peak strongly favors a diagnosis of tuberculosis rather than NCC, which typically does not show this peak. This approach is a non-invasive and specific method to further evaluate the lesions, aligning with standard clinical protocols.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CBNAAT of CSF: CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) of CSF is mainly used for confirming tuberculous meningitis rather than localized brain lesions such as tuberculomas. It is not useful in directly evaluating ring-enhancing lesions seen on MRI.

 

Option C. Biopsy: Biopsy is an invasive procedure and is usually not the first choice due to potential complications. It is reserved for cases where non-invasive methods fail to provide a definitive diagnosis.

 

Option D. SWI (Susceptibility-Weighted Imaging): SWI is used primarily for detecting bleeds, microhemorrhages, or diffuse axonal injuries. It does not contribute to the diagnosis of ring-enhancing lesions caused by infections like tuberculosis or neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal brain region on MRI suggests tuberculomas, and MR spectroscopy is the preferred next step to confirm the diagnosis by detecting a lipid-lactate peak.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a history of progressive weakness, irritability, and delayed growth.  He was started on appropriate treatment at a CHC. A repeat wrist X-ray is performed, as shown. Based on the clinical features and radiographic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Healing Rickets 

 

Healing rickets is characterized by clinical features such as progressive weakness, irritability, and delayed growth, along with radiographic signs of repair and new bone formation at metaphyses seen on wrist X-rays. This phase follows the institution of vitamin D therapy and is marked by metaphyseal sclerosis, cupping, and apparent healing of previously deficient bone.

 

The imaging changes differ from active rickets by showing signs of bone healing and remodeling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-healing rickets: Would show ongoing growth plate widening and metaphyseal cupping without signs of healing or sclerosis.

 

Option B. Scurvy: Typically shows a dense white line of calcification (Frankel's line) and Pelkan spurs; clinical presentation includes bleeding and irritability but radiographs differ.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: Characterized by increased bone density (bone within bone appearance) and no metaphyseal cupping; clinical course includes fractures and growth delay, but radiological appearance is different

choices.text: Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with prostate cancer is being investigated. The bone scan is shown below. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis 

 

Prostate cancer frequently metastasizes to bone, often causing osteoblastic lesions that show as areas of increased radiotracer uptake on bone scans due to increased osteoblastic activity. Diffuse metastatic involvement leads to widespread increased uptake throughout the skeleton visible on the scan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Co-existing multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma typically causes lytic bone lesions that show reduced or normal uptake on bone scans, unlike the increased uptake in osteoblastic metastases.

 

Option C. Normal scan: A normal bone scan would not show diffuse increased uptake; this scan clearly shows abnormal increased tracer accumulation.

 

Option D. Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis causes decreased bone density but does not typically cause increased uptake on bone scans unless there is a fracture or metabolic activity.

questions.text: An ultrasound of a 24-year-old woman shows an endometrium with a classic trilaminar appearance, as seen in the image provided. Which phase of the menstrual cycle does this ultrasound image most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Late Proliferative

 

  • The trilaminar (three-layered) appearance of the endometrium on ultrasound is characteristic of the late proliferative (pre-ovulatory) phase of the menstrual cycle. This phase features a hypoechoic central layer (functional zone), sandwiched by two hyperechoic layers representing the basal layer and interface with the uterine cavity.
  • This pattern develops under the influence of rising estrogen levels before ovulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Secretory: In this phase, the endometrium becomes more uniformly hyperechoic and thicker, losing the trilaminar pattern due to progesterone effect.

 

Option B. Early proliferative: The endometrium is thinner and more homogenous, without a distinct trilaminar pattern.

 

Option C. Menstrual: The endometrium is thin or irregular, often disrupted with low echogenicity, reflecting shedding of the lining.

questions.text: Which of the following will be avid on FDG PET scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atypical carcinoid

 

  • Atypical carcinoid tumors show higher metabolic activity and therefore demonstrate avid uptake on FDG PET scans compared to typical carcinoids.
  • Typical carcinoids often show low or minimal FDG uptake due to their indolent nature and lower glucose metabolism, whereas atypical carcinoids are more aggressive with higher standardized uptake values (SUV) on FDG PET.
  • The difference in FDG avidity helps differentiate atypical from typical carcinoids and has prognostic implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Typical carcinoid: Usually shows low or negligible FDG uptake on PET because of low metabolic rate.

 

Option B. Mucinous adenocarcinoma: Generally shows variable FDG uptake but not characteristic in this context of carcinoids.

 

Option D. Calcified TB granulomas: Typically show low or no FDG uptake as calcifications represent inactive lesions.

choices.text: MRI Diffusion-weighted imaging of the brain

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the casualty after 3 episodes of sudden loss of vision in his right eye like a curtain falling down, each of which resolved spontaneously after about 2 minutes. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes. Neurological examination of the patient is normal. What investigation would aid in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Doppler of the neck

questions.text: Identify the fracture site in the X-ray shown below.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right posterior end of 6th rib

 

The X-ray image shows a fracture indicated by the red arrow at the posterior aspect of the right 6th rib, clearly visible near the vertebral end of the rib in the posterior section of the thoracic cage.

 

NOTE = Horizontal portion of rib is posterior part and curved part is anterior.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented to the clinic with a persistent cough, fatigue, weight loss. Xray of the patient is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TB

 

The chest X-ray shows bilateral upper lobe opacities, cavitary lesions, and fibrosis, which are classic radiological findings of pulmonary tuberculosis. The clinical presentation of chronic cough, weight loss, and fatigue further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergilloma: Typically appears as a rounded mass within a pre-existing cavity, often with an air crescent sign; the current X-ray shows more diffuse cavitary and fibrotic changes.

 

Option C. Carcinoma lung: Usually presents with a localized mass, possibly with associated collapse or effusion, rather than bilateral cavitation and fibrosis.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Characteristically shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy or reticulonodular opacities, less commonly cavitary upper lobe lesions.

choices.text: Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass
Useful in young females with dense breast
Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a benefit of USG compared to Mammography?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable clinically non palpable breast mass 

 

  • Ultrasound is not currently recommended as a primary screening tool for breast cancer because it can miss early signs such as microcalcifications, which mammography detects well. Hence, it is not used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non-palpable masses.
  • Ultrasound is particularly useful in young women with dense breasts, differentiates solid from cystic lesions, and allows guided biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Useful in young females with dense breast: True; ultrasound has higher sensitivity in dense breast tissue where mammography sensitivity reduces.

 

Option C. Differentiates between solid and cystic lesions in the breast: True; ultrasound is effective in distinguishing these lesion types.

 

Option D. Guided biopsy can be done: True; ultrasound-guided biopsy is commonly used for targeted sampling of breast lesions.

questions.text: Cardiac output can be determined using the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coronary angiography

 

  • Cardiac output can be measured using:
    • Pulmonary arterial catheterisation: The gold standard invasive method using thermodilution technique.
    • Cardiac MRI: Non-invasive, accurate for volume and flow measurements to calculate cardiac output.
    • Echocardiography: Non-invasive method using Doppler to estimate stroke volume and cardiac output.
  • Coronary angiography is used for visualizing coronary arteries but does not measure cardiac output directly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary arterial catheterisation: Invasive gold standard for cardiac output measurement.

 

Option C. Cardiac MRI: Accurate for noninvasive cardiac output measurement.

 

Option D. Echocardiography: Widely used for noninvasive cardiac output estimation.

questions.text: A child presents with breathlessness. On chest X-ray, the following object is seen. Identify:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Button battery 

 

The chest X-ray shows a round radio-opaque object with a visible double rim or halo sign, which is characteristic of a button battery lodged in the esophagus. This distinct appearance separates button batteries from other round foreign bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coin: Appears as a single uniform radio-opaque disc without a double rim or halo sign.

 

Option C. Ball: Usually not radio-opaque and would not produce this distinct sign; rarely seen as a foreign body on chest X-ray.

 

Option D. Bottle cap: Unlikely to produce this round, double rim appearance and rarely ingested by children.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a severe, sudden-onset, throbbing headache and double vision for the past 30 minutes. She has a history of migraine and reports frequent headaches. She has not had her period for several months. On examination, her blood pressure is 95/61 mmHg, and visual field testing reveals decreased visual acuity and loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. MRI of brain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pituitary apoplexy

 

The MRI shows a sellar mass with hemorrhagic changes suggestive of pituitary apoplexy. The acute symptoms of sudden severe headache, visual disturbances, hypotension (secondary to acute pituitary hormone deficiency), and history of menstrual irregularities further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transient ischemic attack: Typically presents with brief focal neurological deficits, not sudden visual field loss and is not associated with sellar mass or hypopituitarism.

 

Option C. Sheehan syndrome: Occurs postpartum due to pituitary infarction from hypotension/bleeding, but the patient does not have a peripartum history or acute presentation.

 

Option D. Migraine with aura: While she has a history of migraine, the imaging and endocrine features are not compatible with migraine

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the trauma center after RTA with shortness of breath. The supine CXR is shown below. The BP is 109/88 mmHg and pulse is 98/min. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ICD insertion 

 

The supine chest X-ray reveals a large left sided hemothorax, demands immediate intervention, and intercostal drain (ICD) insertion is the definitive step 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Needle thoracocentesis: Indicated for tension pneumothorax with instability

 

Option C. ET Intubation: Appropriate for respiratory failure or airway compromise.

 

Option D. NG tube insertion: Used for gastrointestinal decompression

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with sudden onset altered semsorium. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pontine hemorrhage

 

The CT image shows a hyperdense area in the region of the pons, which corresponds to an acute hemorrhage in the brainstem. Sudden onset of altered sensorium is a typical presentation, and pontine hemorrhage often occurs in older adults, frequently due to hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertensive hemorrhage: While common, hypertensive bleeds usually occur in basal ganglia, thalamus, or cerebellum rather than isolated pons.

 

Option B. Berry aneurysm rupture: Typically causes subarachnoid hemorrhage, which would present with blood in basal cisterns and sulcal spaces on CT.

 

Option D. EDH (Epidural hematoma): Appears as a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdensity on CT and is not located in the brainstem

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of the condition depicted in the HRCT below?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Aspergillus fumigatus

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the casualty with chest pain radiating to the back. He is diagnosed with a type A aortic dissection and undergoes emergent open repair. During the postoperative period, he develops thoracic back pain and an inability to move his bilateral lower extremities. Pinprick testing reveals bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the xiphoid process. Injury to which of the following arteries most likely explains this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Artery of Adamkiewicz

 

  • The artery of Adamkiewicz, also known as the great anterior radiculomedullary artery, is the principal blood supply to the anterior spinal artery in the thoracolumbar region. 
  • It typically arises between T9 and T12 but can originate anywhere from T8 to L2. 
  • In aortic dissection or during surgical repair, disruption of blood flow to this artery can cause anterior spinal artery syndrome, which manifests as:
  • Motor deficits: Bilateral lower extremity paralysis due to corticospinal tract involvement.
  • Sensory deficits: Loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion due to spinothalamic tract involvement.
  • Preservation of dorsal columns: Fine touch, vibration, and proprioception remain intact as they are supplied by the posterior spinal arteries.
  • The artery of Adamkiewicz is especially vulnerable during thoracic aortic procedures, leading to spinal cord ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior thoracic epidural artery: This artery supplies the epidural space and vertebral bodies and is not directly responsible for spinal cord perfusion.

 

Option C. Posterior spinal arteries: These supply the dorsal columns responsible for proprioception and fine touch, which remain intact in this case.

 

Option D. Middle meningeal artery: This artery supplies the dura mater and calvaria, not the spinal cord, and is unrelated to this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the role of the artery of Adamkiewicz in supplying the thoracolumbar region of the spinal cord.
  • Recognize anterior spinal artery syndrome as a complication of aortic dissection and its repair.
  • Differentiate between vascular territories of the spinal cord and their clinical implications.

questions.text: A patient presents to emergency department with chronic ear discharge and headache with ear pain. CT revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cerebellar abscess

 

The CT scan shows a ring-enhancing lesion in the posterior fossa, specifically within the cerebellum, consistent with a cerebellar abscess. The clinical history of chronic ear discharge (otogenic source) and headache suggests a complication of untreated otitis media or mastoiditis leading to cerebellar abscess formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporal abscess: Would present with a lesion lateral to the posterior fossa, in the temporal lobe.

 

Option B. Occipital abscess: Involvement would be more posterior and superior, not typically in the posterior fossa.

 

Option D. Subdural abscess: Would typically present as a crescentic collection, not a localized ring-enhancing lesion within the cerebellum.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for PTH adenoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tc99-Sestamibi scan

 

The investigation of choice for localizing a parathyroid adenoma is the Tc99-Sestamibi scan. This nuclear medicine scan uses Technetium-99m labeled Sestamibi, which is preferentially taken up by the mitochondria-rich cells of the parathyroid adenoma. Sestamibi accumulates in both thyroid and parathyroid tissue initially, but it washes out faster from the thyroid, allowing for better localization of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

The Tc99-Sestamibi scan is highly sensitive for detecting parathyroid adenomas and is particularly useful in cases of primary hyperparathyroidism, where accurate localization of the adenoma is needed before surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tc99-Pertechnate scan: This scan is used mainly for imaging thyroid tissues, as it gets taken up by functioning thyroid cells. It is not specific for parathyroid adenomas and thus is not the preferred method for localizing parathyroid tissue.

 

Option C. Pertechnate SPECT scan: SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) with pertechnate is generally used for evaluating thyroid conditions. It lacks specificity for parathyroid adenomas, making it less effective than the Sestamibi scan in this context.

 

Option D. CT: While a CT scan can provide anatomical details and may identify large adenomas, it is not as effective as Tc99-Sestamibi in detecting smaller or ectopic parathyroid adenomas. It is often used as a secondary imaging modality if the Sestamibi scan is inconclusive or for surgical planning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Tc99-Sestamibi scan is the preferred imaging modality for localizing parathyroid adenomas, particularly in cases of primary hyperparathyroidism, due to its high sensitivity and ability to differentiate parathyroid from thyroid tissue.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with pain and swelling in the thigh since last one month. X-ray is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ewing sarcoma

 

The X-ray shows periosteal reaction with characteristic "onion-skin" (lamellated) appearance along the diaphysis of a long bone, which is classic for Ewing sarcoma seen in adolescents. The clinical history of rapid progression with pain and swelling supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoclastoma: Typically arises at the epiphysis of long bones and affects young adults.

 

Option C. Brodie abscess: Presents as a well-defined, lucent lesion with surrounding sclerosis, usually not with onion-skin periosteal reaction.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma: Shows sunburst or Codman's triangle periosteal reaction, generally in the metaphyseal region.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the Xray?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Psoriatic arthritis

questions.text: What is the minimum amount of fluid to be detected by this X-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 25 ml

 

The provided X-ray image shows blunting of the costophrenic angle, which suggests the presence of a pleural effusion. On a lateral chest X-ray, it is possible to detect as little as 25 ml of pleural fluid. This makes the lateral view more sensitive than the upright posterior-anterior (PA) chest X-ray for detecting small pleural effusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5 ml of pleural fluid can be enough to cause subtle blunting of the costophrenic angle, which is why it can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

 

Option C. 75 ml or more, detection becomes easier even on a PA upright chest X-ray.

 

Option D. 250 ml is generally considered the amount at which blunting of the costophrenic angle becomes obvious on an upright PA chest X-ray, but smaller amounts like 25 ml can still be detected on the lateral view, as seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lateral chest X-ray can detect as little as 25 ml of pleural fluid, making it a more sensitive option for identifying small pleural effusions compared to an upright PA chest X-ray.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a palpable flank lump whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Congenital PUJ obstruction

choices.text: Reassure the patient and follow up

questions.text: A lady was incidentally diagnosed with a 0.5 cm solid mass in her gall bladder on USG as shown. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reassure the patient and follow up

 

A small gallbladder polyp measuring 0.5 cm (5 mm) is generally considered low risk for malignancy. The likelihood of gallbladder cancer increases significantly with polyps larger than 1 cm. For small polyps (less than 1 cm), the standard management is conservative follow-up with repeat imaging to monitor for any increase in size or change in characteristics.

 

  • Regular follow-up with ultrasound is recommended to ensure that the polyp does not grow in size or develop suspicious features. Typically, follow-up intervals may be every 6 to 12 months, depending on the size and growth rate.
  • Immediate cholecystectomy is generally not indicated for polyps smaller than 1 cm unless the patient has other risk factors (e.g., age >50 years, primary sclerosing cholangitis, or a history of gallstones).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy: This is indicated for gallbladder polyps larger than 1 cm or those that show rapid growth or suspicious features on follow-up imaging. It is not the first choice for a small, asymptomatic 0.5 cm polyp.

 

Option C. Open Cholecystectomy: This is typically reserved for cases where there is a high suspicion of malignancy or if laparoscopic surgery is contraindicated. It is not necessary for a small incidental finding like this.

 

Option D. CECT Abdomen: Further imaging like CECT is not usually required for initial management of a small gallbladder polyp. It is more useful when evaluating larger, suspicious lesions or staging known malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For gallbladder polyps less than 1 cm, conservative management with follow-up imaging is typically appropriate, as the risk of malignancy is low.

choices.text: Obstruction due to a renal stone
Presence of a posterior urethral valve

questions.text: A 4-month-old girl is diagnosed with a febrile urinary tract infection. A voiding cystourethrogram is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this infant's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital short intravesical ureter length

 

The image shows a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), a diagnostic test used to evaluate the anatomy of the bladder and urethra and to detect vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), a condition in which urine flows backward from the bladder into the ureters and kidneys.

 

In this case, the most likely underlying cause is congenital short intravesical ureter length, which predisposes the patient to VUR. Normally, a longer segment of the ureter traverses the bladder wall, creating a one-way valve mechanism that prevents reflux. A short intravesical ureter length means that this valve mechanism is compromised, allowing urine to flow back into the ureters and kidneys when the bladder contracts, leading to VUR and an increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

VUR is a common cause of UTIs in infants, particularly those presenting with febrile UTIs. The VCUG is the gold standard for diagnosing VUR, and the findings in this image are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Damage to the rectovaginal septum: This condition would be associated with pelvic trauma or surgical injury and would not typically cause VUR or be a primary cause of UTIs in infants.

 

Option C. Obstruction due to a renal stone: While kidney stones can cause urinary tract infections due to obstruction, they are relatively rare in infants. The VCUG findings here do not indicate obstruction due to a stone but rather show evidence of reflux.

 

Option D. Presence of a posterior urethral valve: Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are a common cause of obstructive uropathy in male infants. They result in bladder outlet obstruction, not VUR due to a short intravesical ureter. PUV is unlikely in this case, given the patient's gender (female).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is often caused by a congenital short intravesical ureter length, leading to impaired function of the ureterovesical junction and a higher risk of febrile UTIs in infants.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the trauma center after a skid injury, with lower abdominal pain and blood at the meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RGU (Retrograde urethrogram)

 

The presence of blood at the urethral meatus following trauma raises a strong suspicion of a urethral injury. In such cases, attempting to insert a Foley catheter without further evaluation can worsen the injury and cause more complications, including complete disruption of the urethra.

 

Retrograde urethrogram (RGU) is the appropriate next step because it allows visualization of the urethra to determine if there is any disruption or injury. RGU involves injecting contrast into the urethra while taking X-ray images to identify any sites of leakage, strictures, or complete disruptions. This imaging is essential to assess the integrity of the urethra before any catheterization attempts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SPC (Suprapubic catheterization): Suprapubic catheterization is used if a urethral injury is confirmed and urine drainage is needed. It is not the first step before confirming the extent of injury with RGU.

 

Option B. Foley’s catheterization: Foley catheterization is contraindicated if there is suspicion of urethral injury, as it could worsen the damage. RGU should be performed first to evaluate the injury before any attempts at catheterization.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This option is not appropriate in the acute trauma setting where urethral injury is suspected. Prompt diagnosis with RGU is necessary to guide further management and prevent complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with trauma and blood at the urethral meatus, retrograde urethrogram (RGU) is the next best step to evaluate for a possible urethral injury before attempting catheterization or other interventions.

choices.text: Tc99m sulfur colloid scan

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presents to you with jaundice. USG of the liver shows the following abnormality. What is the best investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intra-operative cholangiography

 

The ultrasound image of the liver in a 3-month-old infant presenting with jaundice suggests a condition such as biliary atresia, a congenital disorder where the bile ducts inside or outside the liver do not develop properly, leading to a blockage of bile flow. Biliary atresia is a serious condition that requires early diagnosis and surgical intervention (Kasai procedure) to improve outcomes.

 

Intra-operative cholangiography is considered the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis of biliary atresia. During this procedure, contrast dye is injected directly into the bile ducts, allowing visualization of the biliary tree. It helps to confirm whether there is an obstruction or atresia of the biliary ducts and provides detailed information to guide surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tc99m sulfur colloid scan: This nuclear medicine scan can assess liver function and help differentiate between various causes of neonatal jaundice (e.g., hepatocellular vs. obstructive jaundice). However, it is not as definitive as cholangiography in confirming biliary atresia.

 

Option C. MIBG (Metaiodobenzylguanidine) scan: MIBG is used for imaging neuroendocrine tumors like neuroblastoma. It is not relevant for the diagnosis of biliary atresia.

 

Option D. MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography): MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that provides visualization of the biliary and pancreatic ducts. However, in very young infants, it may not provide adequate resolution to visualize the biliary tree as clearly as intra-operative cholangiography, especially when surgical planning is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants with suspected biliary atresia, intra-operative cholangiography is the best investigation to confirm the diagnosis, as it provides direct visualization of the biliary tree and guides surgical management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department following a fall with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wunderlich phenomenon

 

The CT image shows spontaneous, extensive retroperitoneal hemorrhage around the left kidney without evidence of trauma, tumor, or aneurysm rupture. This is characteristic of Wunderlich syndrome (spontaneous renal hemorrhage), which can present with sudden severe flank pain, vomiting, and hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade 4 renal injury: Typically related to trauma with obvious renal parenchymal lacerations and urinary extravasation; not spontaneous.

 

Option B. Renal cell carcinoma: Mass lesion with or without hemorrhage, but not the classic presentation in this acute setting.

 

Option C. Aortic aneurysm rupture: Would show contained or free retroperitoneal blood closer to the aorta, not centered on the kidney.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to respiratory distress. Severe cough and wheezing began an hour ago while the patient was playing at his cousin’s house. The chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Foreign body aspiration

 

The chest radiograph shows hyperinflation of the right lung with a mediastinal shift to the left, which is characteristic of foreign body aspiration causing partial airway obstruction. The history of sudden onset of respiratory symptoms (cough and wheezing) while playing and the rapid onset of symptoms suggest an acute event like inhalation of a foreign object.

 

Foreign body aspiration often leads to unilateral hyperinflation when the foreign object acts as a ball-valve, allowing air to enter the lung during inspiration but preventing its exit during expiration. This can cause the affected lung to appear hyperlucent (darker) on radiographs due to the trapped air.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaphylaxis: Anaphylaxis can cause respiratory distress, but it typically presents with generalized symptoms like urticaria, angioedema, and hypotension. It is not associated with findings of unilateral hyperinflation on radiographs.

 

Option B. Asthma: Asthma can cause wheezing and respiratory distress, but it usually presents as a chronic condition or with a history of recurrent episodes. Sudden onset during play, especially in a previously healthy infant, is more indicative of foreign body aspiration.

 

Option C. Bronchiolitis: Bronchiolitis is a common cause of respiratory distress in infants but is typically viral in origin (e.g., RSV). It presents with a more gradual onset of symptoms, such as runny nose, cough, and wheezing, rather than the acute presentation seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Foreign body aspiration should be considered in children with a sudden onset of respiratory distress and unilateral hyperinflation on chest radiographs, especially when the symptoms began during play or after eating.

choices.text: Loss of soft tissue planes is the earliest X-ray change of infection
Glass pieces can be seen as radiopaque in X-ray images
Cartilage is not visualized on X-ray.
Live bone is more radio-opaque than dead bone on X-Ray images

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding X-Rays?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Live bone is more radio-opaque than dead bone on X-Ray images.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident (RTA). His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, his pulse is 110 bpm, and his respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. Which of the following will be the next step in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) eFAST

 

In the context of trauma with signs of hemodynamic instability (low blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg and tachycardia at 110 bpm), the priority is to rapidly identify the source of bleeding or internal injuries. The extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST) is a rapid bedside ultrasound examination used to assess for free fluid (blood) in the peritoneal, pericardial, and pleural spaces. This tool is highly effective in evaluating trauma patients with suspected internal bleeding and can be performed quickly without needing to move the patient from the resuscitation area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): While a CECT is useful for detailed imaging of abdominal or chest injuries, it is not the immediate next step in an unstable patient. It requires time for contrast administration and is better suited for stable patients who need a thorough evaluation. Moving an unstable patient to the CT scanner can also be risky.

 

Option C. NCCT (Non-Contrast Computed Tomography): NCCT is typically used for head injuries or specific indications like suspected spinal injuries. It is not indicated as the initial step for a hemodynamically unstable trauma patient with potential internal bleeding, as it doesn’t provide immediate information regarding active bleeding sources in the chest or abdomen.

 

Option D. DPL (Diagnostic Peritoneal Lavage): DPL is an invasive procedure that can be used to detect intra-abdominal bleeding in trauma. However, it has largely been replaced by eFAST due to the non-invasive nature and speed of ultrasound. It is rarely used as the first choice in modern trauma settings, especially when eFAST is available.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable trauma patients, the initial assessment should prioritize rapid identification of internal bleeding. The eFAST exam is the preferred first-line diagnostic tool in such cases due to its speed, non-invasive nature, and ability to guide immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with the history of cough for one week. He also gives a history of hemoptysis for 1 month and fever for 4 days. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LLL consolidation

 

The X-ray shows an area of increased opacity in the lower zone of the left lung, with a clear silhouette sign against the heart border, consistent with left lower lobe (LLL) consolidation. The clinical history of cough, hemoptysis, and fever supports infectious consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lingula consolidation: Would obscure the left heart border rather than the lower zone.

 

Option C. LUL consolidation: Would appear as consolidation in the upper zone, not the lower lobe.

 

Option D. Pericardial effusion: Would present as a globular cardiac silhouette, not a localized lung opacity

questions.text: An 28-year-old man presents with the history of cough for one week. He also gives a history of hemoptysis for 1 month and fever for 4 days. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LUL collapse


The chest X-ray shows features consistent with left upper lobe (LUL) collapse:

 

Veil-like opacity on the left side, which is characteristic of LUL collapse.

 

The Luftsichel sign (meaning "air crescent sign") is visible, indicating a crescent of air around the aortic knuckle, which is a classic sign of left upper lobe collapse.

 

On the lateral view, the white opacity anterior to the heart further supports the diagnosis of LUL collapse.

 

The Luftsichel sign is a key indicator of LUL collapse due to compensatory hyperinflation of the superior segment of the left lower lobe, creating a sickle-shaped air shadow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right middle lobe (RML) consolidation: Incorrect. The abnormality is on the left, not the right, and there is no sign of right middle lobe involvement.

 

Option B. Left lower lobe (LLL) collapse: Incorrect. LLL collapse presents differently on radiographs, typically showing a triangular opacity behind the heart with downward displacement of the diaphragm and hilum, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Pericardial effusion: Incorrect. Pericardial effusion would present as a globular, enlarged cardiac silhouette, which is not present in this X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Luftsichel sign is a hallmark of left upper lobe (LUL) collapse and appears as a crescent-shaped lucency adjacent to the aortic arch on a chest X-ray. This is often accompanied by a veil-like opacity in the anterior aspect of the left lung.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with a history of multiple seizures and developmental delay. On physical examination, you notice facial lesions, hypopigmented macules on the skin, and ungual fibromas. MRI brain is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TSC

 

Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) is a genetic disorder that leads to the development of benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain, skin, kidneys, and heart. Key clinical findings include:

 

  • Seizures (often starting in infancy)
  • Developmental delay
  • Skin findings such as hypopigmented macules (ash-leaf spots), facial angiofibromas, and ungual fibromas. The MRI in this case shows cortical and subcortical tubers, which are characteristic brain lesions in TSC. These lesions can lead to seizures and other neurological problems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NF1 (Neurofibromatosis Type 1): While NF1 can also present with skin lesions, such as café-au-lait spots, it more commonly involves neurofibromas and Lisch nodules (on the iris), and does not typically cause hypopigmented macules or ungual fibromas. Brain imaging in NF1 may show optic gliomas or other neurofibromas, rather than cortical tubers.

 

Option C. VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau disease): VHL is associated with hemangioblastomas in the brain, retina, and spinal cord, as well as an increased risk for renal cell carcinoma and pheochromocytoma. VHL is not associated with hypopigmented skin macules or the brain lesions seen in the provided MRI.

 

Option D. Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome: This rare genetic condition is associated with fibrofolliculomas (skin lesions), lung cysts, and an increased risk of kidney tumors. It does not typically present with seizures or the brain lesions seen in TSC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) is a genetic condition characterized by benign tumors in multiple organs, with hallmark findings of seizures, developmental delay, and distinctive skin lesions (such as ash-leaf spots and facial angiofibromas). The brain MRI typically shows cortical and subcortical tubers, contributing to neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with chronic sinusitis and recurrent respiratory tract infections since childhood. The CXR is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kartagener syndrome

 

Kartagener syndrome is a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) and is characterized by the triad of:

 

  1. Chronic sinusitis
  2. Bronchiectasis (as seen on the chest X-ray)
  3. Situs inversus (reversal of the internal organs)

 

The recurrent respiratory infections and chronic sinusitis are caused by defective ciliary function, leading to poor mucociliary clearance. Bronchiectasis, as seen on the X-ray, is a hallmark of the disease due to repeated infections and damage to the airways over time. The key to diagnosing Kartagener syndrome, as opposed to general primary ciliary dyskinesia, is the presence of situs inversus, which may be visible on imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystic fibrosis: While cystic fibrosis can cause chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis, it is associated with other features like pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption, and is usually diagnosed in early childhood. The absence of gastrointestinal symptoms and other characteristic findings of CF makes it less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Primary ciliary dyskinesia: PCD is closely related to Kartagener syndrome, as they share many features, including ciliary dysfunction leading to respiratory issues. However, Kartagener syndrome is a specific form of PCD where the triad of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, and situs inversus is present. The presence of situs inversus makes Kartagener syndrome the more precise diagnosis here.

 

Option D. Asthma: Asthma can cause recurrent respiratory infections, but it typically presents with episodic wheezing, dyspnea, and a normal chest X-ray. The presence of bronchiectasis on imaging, as well as the history of sinusitis, makes asthma an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is a form of primary ciliary dyskinesia that is characterized by the triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. It results from defective ciliary function, leading to impaired mucociliary clearance and recurrent respiratory infections.

questions.text: What should be done to improve the contrast of an X-ray film in a morbidly obese patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase both KvP and mAs

 

  • In a morbidly obese patient, increasing both kVp (kilovolt peak) and mAs (milliampere-seconds) is recommended to improve image contrast and penetration, ensuring adequate exposure through the thicker body tissues.
  • Higher kVp increases X-ray beam penetration, while increasing mAs boosts the number of X-rays, both changes help produce diagnostic images in obese patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease KVP: Reduces penetration and is not recommended for obese patients as it decreases image clarity.

 

Option B. Increase KVP: Alone improves penetration but may reduce contrast if mAs is not also adjusted.

 

Option C. Increase mAs: Alone increases exposure, but without increased kVp, penetration might remain inadequate.

choices.text: Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith
Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation

questions.text: An 45 year old lady presents with acute abdominal pain and distension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cecal volvulus

 

The abdominal X-ray shows a markedly dilated loop of bowel in the right upper quadrant with presence of haustrae, which is typical of cecal volvulus. This condition presents acutely with pain and distension and features large, air-filled bowel loops that point toward the left upper quadrant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sigmoid volvulus: Usually shows a large, ahaustral bent inner-tube shape loop in the left lower abdomen.

 

Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith: Presents with multiple distended bowel loops but lacks the classic coffee bean appearance of volvulus.

 

Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to perforation: Would show multiple air-fluid levels and possibly free air under the diaphragm, not the pattern seen in this X-ray.

questions.text: Identify the marked segment of liver.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) V

 

The highlighted liver segment is in the anterior part of the right lobe, situated just to the right of the midline and below the plane of the portal vein on this axial CT image, which corresponds to segment V of the liver. Segment V lies inferior to the main portal vein and medial to the gallbladder fossa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. VII: Is located in the posterolateral part of the right lobe, in the upper aspect of the liver, not seen in this section.

 

Option C. III: Lies in the left medial segment, adjacent to the falciform ligament; not in the right lobe.

 

Option D. IVa: Is the superior portion of the left medial segment, located near the midline but higher than segment V.

questions.text: Which of the following contrast media is ionic monomer?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Diatrizoate

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior vena cava 

 

The highlighted structure in the anterior right part of the mediastinum, adjacent to the ascending aorta and right pulmonary artery, is the superior vena cava on this axial CT scan. It is seen as a large vessel draining into the right atrium positioned to the right of the midline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descending aorta: Is located posteriorly and to the left side of the vertebral column.

 

Option C. Ascending aorta: Is more anterior and central, not lateral on the right.

 

Option D. Right pulmonary artery: Sits more posterior and slightly above the superior vena cava.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who had multiple episodes of pain abdomen and passage of foul-smelling greasy stools for the past 5 months shows the following CT findings. The TIGAR-O system used in the assessment of the underlying condition is related to which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Etiology

questions.text: A 40 year old female presents with jaundice and pain abdomen. LFT reveals raised bilirubin and GGT. USG reveals scleroatrophic GB with dilated CDB with impacted calculi. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ERCP

 

This patient has obstructive jaundice due to CBD stone (choledocholithiasis) with dilated CBD and impacted calculus. The immediate step is ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) for stone extraction and biliary decompression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholecystectomy: Indicated for gallbladder pathology, but CBD obstruction must be relieved first with ERCP. Cholecystectomy can be done later (interval).

 

Option C. PET scan: Not relevant; used for cancer staging, not for CBD stones.

 

Option D. MRCP: Useful for diagnosis of choledocholithiasis, but here the diagnosis is already confirmed on USG and patient is symptomatic; management requires intervention (ERCP), not further imaging.

questions.text: During rounds, your senior was discussing the given image. The following is an image of which of the following investigations?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT urography

 

The image shows multiple sequential coronal CT scans demonstrating the kidneys, ureters, and bladder during different phases of contrast excretion, which is characteristic of CT urography. This study provides detailed anatomical and functional information about the entire urinary tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contrast study: A general term, but does not specify the advanced imaging modality seen here.

 

Option B. IVP (Intravenous Pyelogram): Uses X-rays, not CT, and shows less anatomical detail.

 

Option D. NCCT (Non-contrast CT): No contrast, so ureters and bladder would not be visualized.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior mesenteric vein

 

The marked structure on this axial CT scan is located just to the right of the superior mesenteric artery (which arises from the aorta). The vein typically appears larger and more anteriorly placed than the artery, and drains into the portal vein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior mesenteric artery: Sits to the left of the SMV, arising directly from the aorta.

 

Option C. Celiac artery: Originates higher up, above the SMA, and supplies foregut structures.

 

Option D. IVC: Much larger, posterior to the aorta, and is not in the position indicated here.

questions.text: A 20-year-old child presents to the emergency with sudden onset of vision loss in the bilateral temporal fields. MRI was done. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Craniopharyngioma

 

The MRI shows a large, cystic-solid lesion in the suprasellar region, typical of a craniopharyngioma. Sudden bilateral temporal field vision loss suggests compression of the optic chiasm, a classic presentation for craniopharyngioma in young patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pituitary adenoma: Usually enlarges the sella and can cause chiasmal compression, but typically seen as a homogeneous sellar mass.

 

Option C. Rathke cleft cyst: Appears as a small, nonenhancing cyst between the anterior and posterior pituitary.

 

Option D. Meningioma: Can occur anywhere along the dura, may compress the optic chiasm if near it, but is not the typical appearance or location here

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn baby boy is brought to the hospital with difficulty breathing, cyanosis and coughing whenever he is fed. The baby was born full-term via vaginal delivery, and his mother had an uneventful pregnancy. He had a birth weight of 2.8 kg and was discharged from the hospital after 48 hours of observation. On examination, the baby appears to be in respiratory distress, with increased work of breathing and decreased oxygen saturation levels. What would be the best contrast of choice for study?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iohexol

 

  • Iohexol is a nonionic, low-osmolar iodinated contrast agent that is considered safer and better tolerated in neonates and infants for imaging studies. It is suitable for use in this vulnerable age group to minimize adverse reactions, including in studies involving the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Water is not a contrast agent and would not provide adequate imaging contrast.
  • Gastrografin is ionic and usually avoided in newborns due to higher osmolarity and potential complications.
  • Barium is contraindicated if aspiration or perforation is suspected because it can cause severe inflammation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Gastrografin: A hyperosmolar ionic contrast agent, less preferred in neonates due to risk of fluid shifts.

 

Option C. Water: Not radiopaque; not used as a contrast media.

 

Option D. Barium: A contraindicated contrast medium if aspiration or bowel perforation is possible

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty following blunt trauma to the chest. A chest X-ray was done. Among the following radiographs, in which case would you further evaluate the patient before putting a chest tube?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 3, 4

questions.text: What is the best imaging study for diagnosis of cerebral infarct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse weighted MRI 

 

  • Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) MRI is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for detecting cerebral infarction, capable of identifying ischemic changes within minutes after symptom onset, much earlier than CT or other MRI sequences.
  • DWI detects restricted diffusion of water molecules in the infarcted brain tissue, shown as hyperintensity on DWI images, allowing early diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FLAIR MRI: Useful for detecting infarcts after a few hours but less sensitive than DWI for hyperacute infarctions.

 

Option B. Non-contrast CT: Widely used initially for detecting hemorrhage and ruling out mimics but less sensitive for early ischemia.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-enhanced CT): Mainly used for vascular imaging, not the gold standard for infarct diagnosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a severe headache is scheduled to undergo a CT scan. During history taking, which of the following will you definitely ask for before the commencement of the scan?
questions.solution: Ans. B) LMP

choices.text: Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

questions.text: A 28-year-old female has been taking oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for the past 5 years. She presents with abdominal pain and CT scan was done. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Hemangioma

questions.text: Identify the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barium meal

 

The image demonstrates a classic barium meal radiograph, with opacification of the stomach and proximal duodenum, outlining the gastric contour and first part of the small intestine. The study is typically performed to assess the stomach and duodenum for ulcers, masses, or other pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BMFT (Barium meal follow-through): Would include more distal small bowel (jejunum/ileum) opacification after barium passes through, not limited to stomach and duodenum.

 

Option C. Barium enteroclysis: Involves direct infusion of barium into the small intestine and demonstrates detailed small bowel loops, which are not seen here.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method for detecting and localization of tumors associated with pheochromocytomas?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Fluorodopa-PET

choices.text: Spine in lateral flexion & extension view

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who is being treated for rheumatoid arthritis, presented with muscle weakness and rigidity in her upper limbs. Which of the given X-ray views should be performed to evaluate her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spine in lateral flexion & extension view

 

  • In rheumatoid arthritis patients with symptoms like muscle weakness and rigidity, the lateral flexion and extension views of the cervical spine are essential for evaluating dynamic instability, particularly at the atlantoaxial joint (C1-C2), which is commonly involved and can lead to subluxation or spinal cord compression.
  • These views help detect any abnormal movement or subluxation that may not be visible on static X-rays.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Open mouth view: Useful to visualize the odontoid process and C1-C2 relationship but does not assess dynamic instability.

 

Option C. Swimmer's view: Best for visualizing the lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebrae when obscured on lateral views, less relevant for RA upper cervical involvement.

 

Option D. Schuller's view: A specialized view for temporal bone imaging, not related to cervical spine evaluation.

choices.text: Interruption of rugae at ulcer edge

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is being evaluated for epigastric pain and burning sensation for the past few weeks. A barium study was done for the patient. Which of the following findings on barium study would indicate that the ulcer is benign?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Hampton's line

questions.text: Patient with history of tachyarrhythmias is on implantable cardioverter defibrillator. He develops shock. Best method to know the position and integrity of ICD is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plain radiograph

 

  • A plain chest radiograph (X-ray) is the best initial and most practical method to evaluate the position and integrity of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) and its leads. It can quickly show device location, lead placement, fractures, dislodgement, or malfunction.
  • Both posteroanterior (PA) and lateral chest X-rays are recommended for thorough assessment, providing two-plane views to confirm appropriate lead tip positions and device integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CECT: Not routinely used for device evaluation and involves contrast exposure.

 

Option B. MRI: Generally contraindicated or limited in patients with implanted cardiac devices due to risk of electromagnetic interference.

 

Option C. USG: Does not provide adequate imaging of ICD leads or device positioning.

questions.text: Eggshell calcification is seen in all the following, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metastatic lymph nodes

 

Eggshell calcification refers to fine, peripheral rim-like calcification seen in the periphery of lymph nodes. It is characteristically observed in:

 

  • Silicosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Post-radiation therapy lymph nodes (e.g., Hodgkin's lymphoma following irradiation)
  • Coal worker's pneumoconiosis
  • Scleroderma
  • Blastomycosis
  • Amyloidosis
  • Histoplasmosis

 

Metastatic lymph nodes typically do not show eggshell calcification. Instead, they often demonstrate tumor amorphous, irregular, or diffuse calcification patterns depending on the primary.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with delayed developmental milestones presents to the OPD. A T2 weighted MRI is performed, and the imaging result is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Metachromatic leukodystrophy

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lacunar stroke

 

The CT scan shows a small, well-defined area of hypodensity in the region of the basal ganglia/internal capsule, typical for a lacunar infarct. Lacunar strokes result from occlusion of small penetrating arteries, commonly associated with hypertension and diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ICH (Intracerebral hemorrhage): Would present as a hyperdense (bright) area, not hypodense.

 

Option C. MCA embolic stroke: Usually larger cortical infarct, often wedge-shaped.

 

Option D. MCA thrombotic stroke: Also tends to be larger and involves cortical and subcortical regions.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student who had a history of frequent respiratory infections as a child presents to the OPD. He has been experiencing recurrent episodes of coughing and shortness of breath over the past few months. He also complains of fatigue and chest pain, particularly on the left side. The CT scan reveals a mass in the lower lobe of his left lung as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Sequestration

questions.text: What is the appearance of CSF on T1 weight MRI-T2 weighted MRI -FLAIR respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypointense - Hyperintense - Hypointense

 

The appearance of CSF on MRI sequences is:

 

  • On T1-weighted MRI: CSF is hypointense (dark).
  • On T2-weighted MRI: CSF is hyperintense (bright).
  • On FLAIR: CSF is hypointense (dark) because the FLAIR sequence suppresses the CSF signal.

choices.text: The higher the pitch, the lower will be the CT quality
Helical CT is faster than non-helical CT
The higher the pitch, the higher will be the radiation dose

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement about CT?
questions.solution: Ans. D) The higher the pitch, the higher will be the radiation dose

questions.text: The following CXR appearance is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulmonary edema

 

The chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral perihilar opacities, a "batwing" pattern, and increased interstitial markings, consistent with pulmonary edema. This appearance is typical in congestive heart failure or fluid overload, where fluid accumulates in the lungs’ interstitium and alveoli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Usually does not show diffuse haziness; may show wedge-shaped infarcts or be normal.

 

Option C. Pneumoconiosis: Characterized by small nodular or reticulonodular opacities, predominantly in the upper zones.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Involves hilar lymphadenopathy and reticulonodular infiltration rather than diffuse edema.

questions.text: The imaging shows a detailed cross-sectional view of the esophageal wall and surrounding structures. All of the following are uses of this imaging modality except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Evaluation of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

questions.text: Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrograde pyelogram

 

The abdominal X-ray reveals contrast outlining the renal pelvis and ureters ascending from the bladder, a classic image for a retrograde pyelogram. This procedure involves injecting contrast directly into the ureters via a cystoscope from the bladder upwards, useful for evaluating ureteric anatomy and pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IVU (Intravenous Urogram): Contrast would be visualized after intravenous injection and excretion by the kidneys, typically showing calyces and renal pelvis first, then progressing down the ureters.

 

Option C. Ureteric stent: Would show a radiopaque stent along the ureter, not contrast outlining the urothelium.

 

Option D. MCU with vesico-ureteric reflux: A micturating cystourethrogram shows bladder filling and possible reflux of contrast up the ureters during voiding, but the image does not match that pattern.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CPAM

 

Explanation:

 

The images provided, including ultrasound, CT scan, and X-ray findings, are consistent with Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM).

 

Key features of CPAM:

 

  1. Ultrasound: Shows multiple cystic spaces within the lung parenchyma.
  2. CT scan: Confirms the presence of air-filled cystic lesions in the lung fields.
  3. X-ray: May show cystic areas or hyperinflation, depending on the size and type of lesions.

 

CPAM is a congenital condition characterized by abnormal development of the lung tissue, leading to the formation of cystic or adenomatoid lesions. It often presents in childhood with recurrent respiratory infections due to impaired drainage and ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyopneumothorax: This would present with an air-fluid level and features of infection (fever, acute symptoms), which are not the primary findings here.

 

Option C. CDH (Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia): CDH presents with abdominal contents herniating into the thoracic cavity, causing mediastinal shift and respiratory distress, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: Lung abscess typically presents as a thick-walled cavity with air-fluid levels, which is not the pattern seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) presents with recurrent respiratory infections due to abnormal lung development and cystic changes. Imaging studies, including ultrasound and CT, confirm the diagnosis by identifying multiple cystic lesions within the lung.

choices.text: Absent breath sounds on the left side

questions.text: A child was intubated, and post-intubation X-ray is shown below. What would be the presenting symptom?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Absent breath sounds on the left side

 

The post-intubation chest X-ray demonstrates the endotracheal tube tip positioned deep in the right main bronchus, causing right lung ventilation and complete collapse of the left lung. This results in absent breath sounds on the left side due to under-ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right sided tracheal deviation: Would occur with volume loss, not the situation here.

 

Option B. Gastric distension: Suggests esophageal intubation rather than selective bronchial intubation.

 

Option C. Drooling on feeding: Associated with esophageal atresia or tracheoesophageal fistula, unrelated to this X-ray finding.

questions.text: In patients with renal failure, which imaging technique is appropriate for visualizing vessels without causing further renal impairment?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Time-of-flight MRI angiography

questions.text: Which imaging modality is typically used to diagnose dysphagia lusoria?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Computed tomography angiography

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with a history of progressive vision loss in her right eye. An MRI of the orbit reveals a lesion with a characteristic appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the MRI findings?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Optic nerve glioma

questions.text: All of the following are considered radioprotectors, except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Cisplatin

choices.text: Radiography uses tungsten as the target, while mammography uses molybdenum
Beryllium is used as the exit window in mammography
Mammography uses Bremsstrahlung radiation for better tissue contrast

questions.text: All of the following are correct differences between normal radiography and mammography, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Mammography uses Bremsstrahlung radiation for better tissue contrast

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the skeletal survey of a 10-year-old boy with recurrent fractures?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Osteopetrosis
